FROM THE WINY RADIO NEWSROOM: Judge dismisses some charges against Trump in the Georgia election interference case

ATLANTA (AP) ‚Äî The judge overseeing the Georgia election interference case on Wednesday dismissed some of the charges against former President Donald Trump, but many other counts in the indictment remain.

Fulton County Superior Court Judge Scott McAfee wrote in an order that six of the counts in the indictment must be quashed, including three against Trump, the presumptive 2024 Republican presidential nominee.

But the order leaves intact other charges, and the judge wrote that prosecutors could seek a new indictment on the charges he dismissed.

The six charges in question have to do with soliciting elected officials to violate their oaths of office. That includes two charges related to the phone call Trump made to Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, a fellow Republican, on Jan. 2, 2021.

‚ÄúAll I want to do is this. I just want to find 11,780 votes, which is one more than we have,‚Äù Trump said.

The case accuses Trump and 18 others of conspiring to overturn his 2020 election loss in the state to Democrat Joe Biden. Trump has pleaded not guilty.

The ruling comes as McAfee is also considering a bid by defendants to have Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis removed from the case. Defendants have alleged that Willis has a conflict of interest because of her romantic relationship with special prosecutor Nathan Wade.

The judge overseeing the Georgia election interference case has dismissed some of the charges against ex-President Donald Trump, but others remain. Judge McAfee wrote Wednesday in an order that six of the charges in the indictment must be quashed, including three against Trump. (AP Photo/Brynn Anderson, Pool, File)

Donald Trump‚Äôs hush-money trial will go ahead as scheduled with jury selection starting on March 25, a judge ruled on Thursday, turning aside requests for a delay from the former president‚Äôs defence lawyers.

In leaving the trial date intact, Judge Juan Manuel Merchan took advantage of a delay in a separate prosecution in Washington charging Trump with plotting to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.

That case has been effectively on hold pending the outcome of an appeal from Trump.

The hearing was held in the same Manhattan courtroom where he pleaded not guilty last April to 34 counts of falsifying business records in an alleged scheme to bury stories about extramarital affairs that arose during his 2016 presidential campaign.

Trump entered the courthouse shortly before 9am.

It was Mr Trump‚Äôs first return visit to court in the New York criminal case since that historic indictment made him the first ex-president charged with a crime.

Since then, he has also been indicted in Florida, Georgia and Washington DC.

In recent weeks, he has blended campaign events with court appearances, attending a closed hearing on Monday in a Florida case charging him with hoarding classified records.

Judge Merchan has taken steps in recent weeks to prepare for a trial. If it goes off as planned, it would be the first of Mr Trump‚Äôs criminal cases to go to trial.

text_trans:
The Biden administration is reportedly considering using executive authority to impose harsh immigration measures, including a push to end asylum for migrants crossing between ports of entry at the US-Mexico border‚Äîa move that the Trump administration tried in 2018 and was shot down by the courts.

The measures, which NBC News first reported on Wednesday, would mimic some of the provisions included in the now-dead Senate bipartisan border deal, including raising the standards for the initial asylum screening known as a ‚Äúcredible fear‚Äù interview. Biden‚Äôs plans would also instruct US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers to prioritize the removal of new migrants in what officials familiar with the discussions described to NBC News as a ‚Äúlast in, first out‚Äù policy. 

It‚Äôs unclear whether or how the White House would move forward with these changes. But the fact that they‚Äôre under consideration underscores the president‚Äôs shift towards stricter border enforcement at the expense of the asylum system, as I‚Äôve written about before. In 2020, Biden pledged a humane immigration policy as a change from Trump. Now, he is promising to ‚Äúshut down the border.‚Äù

The Biden administration has already imposed limitations on asylum, including by making it harder for migrants to qualify if they hadn‚Äôt first sought and been denied humanitarian relief in other countries on the way to the United States. Now, the White House is floating around the idea of using an authority under section 212(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act that allows presidents to suspend the entry of certain foreigners into the country if they find that it ‚Äúwould be detrimental to the interests of the United States.‚Äù

Former President Donald Trump infamously weaponized this authority against travelers from Muslim-majority countries. He also invoked it in 2018 to crackdown on asylum for migrants crossing outside ports of entry, but a federal judge ultimately blocked the policy, writing that ‚Äúwhatever the scope of the president‚Äôs authority, he may not rewrite the immigration laws to impose a condition that Congress has expressly forbidden.‚Äù

A Texan woman discovered two shipwrecks that gave unparalleled insight into life 400 years earlier.

During a violent storm in April 1554, four Spanish Plate Fleet vessels became separated en route from Veracruz, Mexico to Spain. Only one ship, the San Andres, would safely arrive at Havana, Cuba, though heavily damaged‚Äîthe remainder of the fleet ran aground and sank off present-day Padre Island, Texas.

Two of the three shipwrecks (Esp√≠ritu Santo and San Esteban) were discovered in the 1960s, and the third vessel (Santa Mar√≠a de Yciar) is as yet undiscovered, presumed destroyed by the dredging and creation of Mansfield Cut. These wrecks are the oldest excavated shipwrecks in the United States.

For too long the story of the woman who discovered the wrecks, Vida Lee Connor, has been overlooked. So much importance has been placed on the remarkable shipwrecks themselves, including their lasting impact on underwater archeology, that her unique element of the story has been largely forgotten.

Read the THC‚Äôs blog post to learn about Connor‚Äôs extraordinary life: https://thc.texas.gov/blog/vida-lee-connor-discoverer-1554-spanish-plate-fleet-padre-island

In 1990, Maria Rodriguez started "Pi√±ateria la Mexicana.‚Äù This marked the beginning of her commitment to bringing joy to countless children's parties, where generations have celebrated with the iconic Mexican pi√±ata.

Crafting these festive items is considered an art form for Maria, as she consistently receives custom requests from clients. Whether it's replicating a hero from an action movie or creating a princess for young girls, the unique and often intricate demands of customers require extra effort and skill.

In addition to pi√±atas, Maria expanded her business by offering rental services for children's party furniture, including chairs and tables, along with providing tablecloths and selling candy bags.

Reflecting on her early days working in a local meat-packing company, Maria acknowledges the leap of faith she took to pursue her own business. With unwavering support from her family, Maria has not only sustained but also enriched her venture. Her family actively participates in the pi√±ata-making process, with even her children and grandchildren contributing to the creative and hands-on aspect of the business.

Turning Pain into Purpose

Losing a child is a parent's worst nightmare! As you can imagine, it's painful. Erica and Avimael Qui√±ones know that pain firsthand. However, they are now using that tragedy to set an inspiring example.

In 2020, their 4-year-old daughter, Averi, faced a bone cancer diagnosis, prompting the couple to confront the disease head-on in a determined effort to save her. Initiating a GoFundMe account, they embarked on Averi‚Äôs chemotherapy journey, receiving support from thousands of compassionate people. While Erika continued her work at a pharmacy, Abimael grappled with unemployment brought on by the pandemic.

Despite their collective efforts and the unwavering support of family and the community, August 2020 brought the devastating news of Averi‚Äôs passing at the age of 5, leaving her parents and siblings in profound grief.

In tribute to Averi, Erika and Abimael established a non-profit called "The Averi Foundation." The foundation has already helped more than 12 children facing similar health challenges, thanks to the generosity of donors. With a commitment to expanding their reach, the Qui√±ones family organizes fundraising activities, ensuring the legacy of a little girl who embodied dedication and resilience continues to impact lives.

Their sole objective is to give back to the community, acknowledging that the parents and families of children battling illness often endure severe economic hardships.

From archaeology to algorithms, my career trajectory toward High Performance Computing (HPC) was anything but conventional. Departing my role as Coordinator of Latin American Research at the Smithsonian Institution to join my family in Houston, I found myself at a crossroads. Responding to a job posting for a research coordinator at the Texas Learning and Computation Center at the University of Houston, little did I know that the interview would propel me into the world of HPC.

Upon assuming my position, the center transitioned to managing all research HPC operations for the university. Leveraging my background in anthropology, I facilitated communication between professors and the technical team, ensuring the optimal utilization of resources such as compute and storage clusters, along with a cutting-edge visualization laboratory. My interactions with researchers and tech staff honed my expertise.

Under the mentorship of Dr. Lennart Johnsson, a pioneering figure in HPC, my role evolved, resulting in a promotion to Associate Director of TLC2. Dr. Johnsson's guidance and support provided me with insights into establishing and managing an HPC center. I learned how to calculate airflow and designed a power distribution system for our inaugural cluster.  
I participated in the negotiation and implementation of the Research and Education Network of Houston, a robust infrastructure connecting academic institutions that created the cornerstone to the State of Texas research network, the Lonestar Education And Research Network. 

I built collaborations merging humanities and technology, such as partnering with the Moore's Opera to create 3D sets‚Äîa feat preceding the Metropolitan Opera's endeavor by six months.

I have demonstrated my commitment to diversity and inclusion in tech, notably through speaking engagements at summer camps for girls and minority youth, and obtaining certification in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion from Cornell. I aspire to empower Hispanic and LatinX women to assume prominent roles in HPC, bridging the gap in representation.
My name is Rosalinda M√©ndez and I am the CEO of NOA Research, LLC. #whm2024 #sc24 #hpccreates

TWO YOUNG MESCALERO APACHE MEN, 1888
The Mescalero Apaches were a semi-nomadic people who once roamed the area of New Mexico, West Texas, and Chihuahua. The word "Apache" means "enemy" in the Zu√±i language, as they were feared by the pueblo tribes of northern New Mexico as well by the Spanish. The Gila and Chiricahua Apaches were to the west and the Lipan Apaches to the east, but the Mescaleros were once the largest and most powerful Apache nation among them.
The Mescaleros are documented archeologically in our region as early as the thirteenth century. They began raiding local Spanish settlements and traveling caravans starting in the 1680s. Between 1778 and 1825 there was a large band of Mescaleros encamped on the future site of Duranguito and Downtown El Paso, peaking at about one thousand men, women and children in the 1790s.
The Spanish, Mexicans and Americans all waged wars of extermination against this proud and fierce people. Today the remaining Mescaleros possess a small reservation in southern New Mexico.

What a great turnout at La Mesa in Poteet for Irma Olivares‚Äô book signing.

Pleasanton Express will be writing a feature on Irma and her new historical fiction book‚ÄùLos Tejanos De Bexar.‚Äù

The Pleasanton Express has signed paperback copies that we will be giving away! 

 ‚ÄúLos Tejanos Bexar‚Äù

1835 deep in the Mexican state of Texas. The once peaceful city of Bexar, with its fiestas and fandangos, has come under attack by Mexican General Santa Anna who is determined to bend the Bexarenos to his will. They are determined to do theirs. Already there has been house to house fighting with fatalities. How much more can the citizens of Bexar endure?

Many Bexarenos face a difficult choice: fight to free Texas from Santa Anna's tyrannical grip or remain loyal to their mother country, Mexico.

For Alejandro Casta√±on, who fled Ciudad de M√©xico with his daughter Cristina to leave what he saw as the political injustices of Santa Anna behind, the decision seems clear. 

However not everyone agrees with him, and some begin to question his loyalty, even to his family. To make matters more complicated, Norte Americanos arrive daily in preparation for war against Santa Anna inviting anyone who wants a better way of life to join them.

The Curandera saw blood and death for the Bexarenos. Was she right? Can Alejandro go against his family and friends? Will any stand with him? And what if they should lose?

In Los Tejanos de Bexar, author Irma Olivares retells the famous story of the battle of the Alamo from the often forgotten perspective of the ordinary Mexicans and Spaniards who fought on the Texas side. Known as Tejanos, the role of these men and women was often underplayed or completely left out of history books, until now.

text_trans: On this day in 1907, Justina Luckenbach died, four years to the day before the death of her husband Jacob. Both Luckenbachs were born in Germany and came to Texas in late 1845. In January 1846 they were among the first settlers in Fredericksburg. Jacob Luckenbach was allocated a town lot in the new village and a ten-acre lot southwest of town, where he built the family's first home. The Luckenbach family became American citizens in 1852 and shortly thereafter sold both Fredericksburg properties and moved twelve miles southeast. When she was appointed postmistress at the site, Sophie Engel named the post office Luckenbach in honor of her fianc√©, Jacob and Justina's son Albert. Jacob and Justina Luckenbach raised three boys and nine girls in all. In 1883 they sold their property in Luckenbach and retired in Boerne, to be near six of their children who lived there. The population of Luckenbach peaked at 492 in 1904, but declined dramatically in the following decades. John Russell (Hondo) Crouch, from nearby Comfort, bought the "town" in 1971. Styling himself the "mayor" and "Clown Prince of Luckenbach," Crouch declared Luckenbach "a free state...of mind." Popularized in regional culture as the place where "Everybody is Somebody," Luckenbach achieved mythic proportions in 1977, the year after Crouch's death, when the Waylon Jennings song "Luckenbach, Texas (Back to the Basics of Love)" became a national favorite. https://bit.ly/3UQUnY4 ~~ On This Day entries are brought to you by the TSHA. Today was filled with mixed emotions. We sent a few Rehabbers/Transporters from our team, to the wildfire stricken areas, to look for orphaned and injured wildlife. We covered almost 300 miles over the course of 9.5 hours. 

The pictures and videos you see online/television of the damage don‚Äôt do justice to seeing it in person. The devastation is insurmountable.  Many people lost their entire homes, vehicles, herds, and a few, even their lives. 

It is easy to be overcome with the reality of it all.  Especially when the fires are still burning. However, you have to focus on how ‚Äúyou‚Äù as an organization or person can help and do that! Collectively, when everyone works together, we as a community persevere. And that is what we saw. 

On the way to Fritch, Borger, Pampa, and Canadian we passed multiple trucks, semis, and vehicles pulling flatbeds with supplies (hay, feed, barbed wire‚Ä¶).  It reminds you that there is far more good in the world than bad. 

We did not see any wildlife in need on this day and only a few that didn‚Äôt make it. It was a pleasant surprise. We can‚Äôt forget, wild animals are smart, and can sense things even before us.  Even while walking the Gene Howe Wildlife Management √Årea we were reminded of that. While walking through smoldering ground we saw fresh footprints of animals like raccoons, opossums, coyotes, and much more by the water. They made it!!

We also made new connections in those areas with law enforcement, biologists, and game wardens who didn‚Äôt know there was a wildlife rehabilitation facility in the Texas Panhandle.  Those new relationships will help more wildlife for years to come. 

Lastly, we have had an influx of animals but mainly from the high winds, which continue tomorrow.  We have now taken in over 11 baby squirrels in the past few days and multiple birds. Thank you for your continued support via Amazon supplies, monetary donations, and sharing our posts. We love our wildlife in the Texas Panhandle and cannot do it without you.

This exhibition came together from the idea of wanting to provide a beautiful and safe environment for clients and families at Safe Place.

The Apache are several Southern Athabaskan language‚Äìspeaking peoples of the Southwest and the Southern Plains. They are linguistically related to the Navajo. They migrated from the Athabascan homelands in the north into the Southwest between 1000 and 1500 CE.

Apache bands include the Chiricahua, Jicarilla, Lipan, Mescalero, Mimbre√±o, Salinero, Plains, and Western Apache (Aravaipa, Pinale√±o, Coyotero, and Tonto). Today, Apache tribes and reservations are headquartered in Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, and Oklahoma. Each tribe is politically autonomous.

Historically, the Apache homelands have consisted of high mountains, sheltered and watered valleys, deep canyons, deserts, and the southern Great Plains, including areas in what is now Eastern Arizona, Northern Mexico (Sonora and Chihuahua) and New Mexico, West Texas, and Southern Colorado. These areas are collectively known as Apacheria.

The Apache tribes fought the invading Spanish and Mexican peoples for centuries. The first Apache raids on Sonora appear to have taken place during the late 17th century. In 19th-century confrontations during the American Indian Wars, the U.S. Army found the Apache to be fierce warriors and skillful strategists.

The Apache are several Southern Athabaskan language‚Äìspeaking peoples of the Southwest and the Southern Plains. They are linguistically related to the Navajo. They migrated from the Athabascan homelands in the north into the Southwest between 1000 and 1500 CE.

Apache bands include the Chiricahua, Jicarilla, Lipan, Mescalero, Mimbre√±o, Salinero, Plains, and Western Apache (Aravaipa, Pinale√±o, Coyotero, and Tonto). Today, Apache tribes and reservations are headquartered in Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, and Oklahoma. Each tribe is politically autonomous.

Historically, the Apache homelands have consisted of high mountains, sheltered and watered valleys, deep canyons, deserts, and the southern Great Plains, including areas in what is now Eastern Arizona, Northern Mexico (Sonora and Chihuahua) and New Mexico, West Texas, and Southern Colorado. These areas are collectively known as Apacheria.

The Apache tribes fought the invading Spanish and Mexican peoples for centuries. The first Apache raids on Sonora appear to have taken place during the late 17th century. In 19th-century confrontations during the American Indian Wars, the U.S. Army found the Apache to be fierce warriors and skillful strategists.

In today's fast-paced consumer markets, industrial wastewater and undesirable by-products can pose significant challenges. However, effective processing of this type of waste can lead to converting it into a reusable product or treating it suitably for safe release back into the environment. This is where KlipTank comes in.

At KlipTank, we specialise in providing solutions for processing industrial waste. Our expertise lies in converting waste into a reusable resource or treating it appropriately to minimise its environmental impact. 

We understand that many industrial by-products contain chemical components, and as such, we offer a variety of liner material options to suit specific needs. Whether it's exchanging galvanized wire ropes for stainless steel or providing chemical-resistant fittings, we can tailor our tanks to meet the specific requirements of your operation.

Ready to explore our industrial waste processing solutions? Contact our friendly team to discuss your specific requirements today. Call us on 0800 225 222 or visit https://kliptank.com/

Adra Group Acquires Maclean & Lawrence
PRESS RELEASE 1 June 2021

The addition of Maclean & Lawrence to the Adra Group of companies will enhance the services available to our clients and support the overall growth strategy of the Company.
Maclean & Lawrence was first established in 1956 and has established a niche operation within the Western Australian construction industry as Hydraulic Services Consulting Engineers.
With a focus on Hydraulic Services, Maclean & Lawrence has been involved with a diverse range of projects across Western Australia - from Broome to Esperance, Kalgoorlie to the Perth metropolitan area.
In summary, Maclean & Lawrence assist its clients with ensuring the efficient, hygienic, safe and legal collection, storage, control, transport, regulation, measurement and use of water or the by-products of water (wastewater & sewage).
‚ÄúThis acquisition demonstrates our commitment to provide exceptional engineering services to our customers and to expand these services to the former Maclean & Lawrence customers. We are excited to integrate with the loyal customers and employees in Western Australia

This happened last weekend in Vermont...the operational and engineering ineptitude of Casella Waste Systems on full display.  Keep in mind, this is the same company whose NCES Landfill in Bethlehem, NH has contaminated the surrounding watershed of the Ammonoosuc River, with NCES surface water runoff containing PFAS contaminants being released directly into the Ammonoosuc River. ** Fukushima **
 
A new documentary that questions whether it is right to sacrifice a community's way of life for the betterment of the wider public has revealed the turmoil and hardships faced by those who were displaced in the wake of the 2011 Fukushima nuclear power plant disaster. "Tsushima: Fukushima Speaks Part 2," directed by freelance journalist Toshikuni Doi, features the testimonies of people seeking the return of their hometown, which was deemed uninhabitable for a century after the world's worst nuclear accident since the 1986 Chernobyl meltdown.
 
Japan Times 12th March 2024
https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2024/03/12/japan/society/japan-fukushima-displacement/
 
The head of the U.N. atomic agency on Wednesday told local Japanese representatives at a meeting in Fukushima that the ongoing discharge of treated radioactive wastewater at the ruined nuclear power plant has met safety standards and that any restrictions on products from the region are "not scientific." International Atomic Energy Agency Director-General Rafael Grossi joined local officials and representatives from fishing and business groups and reassured them that the discharges are being carried out "with no impact to the environment, water, fish and sediment." Grossi, who arrived in Japan on Tuesday, returned to Fukushima for the first time since the release of the treated water began in August.

Fact Check: Lawrence drinking water remains safe and clean

We've received a number of questions about the safety of the drinking water in town stemming from information that there has been an increase in the concentration of hepatitis A virus (HAV) detected in our WASTEWATER. We would like to clear the confusion for our community and reiterate that drinking water provided by the City of Lawrence is clean and safe to use.

Wastewater, also called sewage, is produced when people flush the toilet, drain the bathtub, take a shower or use a sink. That water flows to a wastewater treatment plant. Wastewater should not be confused with drinking or tap water.

More information in this release with Lawrence-Douglas County Public Health: https://lawrenceks.org/2024/02/22/fact-check-lawrence-drinking-water-remains-safe-and-clean

üíß Clogging Pipes: Flushable wipes may claim to be safe for flushing, but they don't break down as easily as toilet paper. This can lead to nasty clogs in both household and municipal sewage systems.

üîß These wipes can cause serious damage to sewage systems, resulting in costly repairs for both homeowners and municipalities. Let's save ourselves the headache of plumbing problems!

üåç When wipes clog up sewage systems, they can lead to overflows that release untreated wastewater into our water bodies. This harms our environment and aquatic life.

üîç Despite being labeled as "flushable," these wipes don't disintegrate quickly enough to be safe for flushing. Let's not be fooled by misleading packaging!

üóëÔ∏è Instead of flushing flushable wipes, let's dispose of them in the trash where they belong. It's a small change that can make a big difference in preventing clogs, protecting our infrastructure, and preserving our environment.

Together, let's make sure we're not contributing to the problem. Remember: when in doubt, throw it out! üóëÔ∏èüíö

Around Home

Use less water so excess runoff and wastewater will not flow into the ocean.

Cut down on what you throw away.

Choose sustainable seafood. Buy less plastic and bring a reusable bag.
‚Ä¢ 5. Reduce Vehicle Pollution
Use fuel efficient vehicles, carpool or ride a bike.
‚Ä¢ 6. Use Less Energy

On the Water

Follow "catch and release" practices and keep more fish alive.
‚Ä¢ 8. Practice Safe Boating
Anchor in sandy areas far from coral and sea grasses. Adhere to "no wake" zones.
‚Ä¢ 9. Respect Habitat
Healthy habitat and survival go hand in hand. Treat with care.

7. Fish Responsibly- Follow "catch and release" practices and keep more fish alive.

8. Practice Safe Boating- Anchor in sandy areas far from coral and sea grasses. Adhere to "no wake" zones.

9. Respect Habitat- Healthy habitat and survival go hand in hand. Treat with care.

10. Volunteer!- Volunteer Volunteer for cleanups at the beach and in your community. You can get involved in protecting your watershed too!
